Cupriavidus necator H16 is a Gram-negative, aerobic, non-spore-forming, and motile bacterium belonging to the Betaproteobacteria class. It is commonly known as a hydrogen-oxidizing bacterium due to its ability to utilize hydrogen as a source of energy for growth.

The species Cupriavidus necator H16 is known for its versatility in metabolizing a wide range of organic compounds, including sugars, organic acids, and various aromatic compounds. This ability makes it a valuable candidate for applications in bioremediation, biofuel production, and the synthesis of bioplastics.

One of the distinctive features of C. necator H16 is its capacity to accumulate polyhydroxyalkanoates (PHAs), which are biodegradable and renewable biopolymers. This property has attracted significant interest in the field of sustainable materials and the development of eco-friendly alternatives to traditional plastics.

Furthermore, C. necator H16 has been studied for its potential in hydrogen production, as it can utilize hydrogen as an energy source and convert it into biomass. This characteristic has implications for the development of clean energy technologies and the mitigation of greenhouse gas emissions.

Overall, Cupriavidus necator H16 is a versatile and metabolically diverse bacterium with numerous applications in biotechnology, environmental remediation, and sustainable development.
